texts.shortText: Large, tall heron with white head and long, sharply-pointed, pinkish beak; head with broad, horizontal, black stripe extending from eye to 2-3 long black plumes extending from nape. Neck white with broken black stripes down front. Back, tail and wings grey, wings with black shoulders. Legs and feet pinkish.
Total length 90-98 cm, mass 1-2 kg, sexes alike.

Global: Widespread across sub-Saharan Africa, Europe and Asia.

Local/Regional: Widespread inland and along the coast, except in Namibia, Northern Cape and Kalahari, where rare.

Fairly common along the margins of various inland water bodies, as well as along the coastline, rarely also in dry grassland. Usually solitary and active both by day and night. Usually seen standing motionless in or next to water, rapidly striking to spear or grasp prey in beak. Small items may be immediately swallowed alive, but larger ones are shaken or stabbed to death then manipulated into a head-first position before being swallowed.
Feeds mainly on fish, but also take crustaceans, molluscs and other invertebrates (also frogs, reptiles and small rodents and birds when in freshwater).

Monogamous and usually nests in colonies, sometimes mixed among other water birds. Nest a large basin of sticks and reeds lined with grass and other softer materials, may be placed on top of an earlier nest, resulting in a massive structure. Usually placed above water, built by female from material supplied by male. Eggs 1-4, oval and pointed at both ends, blue or greenish blue, in Western Cape laid mainly July - January. Incubation period 23-28 days. Young fully fledged by 28 days, nestlings compete and younger chicks of larger broods progressively smaller, youngest seldom survive. Leave nest at about 20 days and sit on nearby branches, where continue to be fed by both adults.
Similar to Black-headed heron, but that has black back up to head and neck and is largely terrestrial and seldom found on the shore.
